comments.commentBody:
Argentina meets Greenwich Village.
That could account for the interesting and unusual piece. Now I can add bandoneon and Piazzolla to what I learned today. Apparently Piazzolla was taught to play Bach on his bandoneon when he was 12 by Bela Wilda, who had himself been a student of Rachmaninoff.

Per previous, here's what a well-known newspaper wrote about (((name))) --

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/10/business/media/to-beat-anti-semitic-tr...

Good call.  No reason to have to put up with this nonsense.  With almost 325 million Americans and growing, there are going to be some haters and tribalists but no doubt what you experienced on Twitter is not representative of the feelings of the vast majority.  It is even more liberating to give up Facebook as well.  And kudos to the NY Times for not requiring mandatory social media participation as part of the modern employment environment (or for comments, as some media outlets do).  It is a strange time in America and social media has not necessarily been a net positive.  As to the merits of Mr. Kagan's argument itself, I do think it would have been stronger coming from someone like Rabbi Lerner of Tikkun rather than a  neo-con interventionist.

You're over-reacting. There was nothing Mr. Weisman wrote that said that Taylor Swift had solicited the adoration of White Nationalists. To the contrary, it was quite clear from the phrase "adopted as the..." that Taylor Swift has nothing to do with this, so nothing needs to be clarified.

Instead of searching for non-existent slurs how about we concentrate on the real life hatred, such as what was written about in Mr. Weisman's column.

It's not just Twitter. Noxious fumes emanating from the social media swamp are getting worse ... unvarnished bigotry; ISIS propaganda; cyberbullying and suicide; and the racist tirades of a presumptive presidential nominee. It's a toxic fog and overexposure can be harmful to one's health.

Silicon Valley could do more, but it chooses not to. Perhaps if others followed suit, Twitter et al would finally take the issue seriously. Maybe more of us should follow Hillary's advice: delete your account.

Exactly. I have 2 followers and 1 of then is my daughter. But it gives me capsules news and links to more extensive articles. I think the trouble starts when one uses Twitter as an ego game: how many followers can I collect? In a lot of ways Twitter is a mirror. Just stop the fond gaze and you'll be okay.

I use twitter as a news feed and I don't comment or engage with anybody.

I find it useful and I haven't had any problems with any types of haters.
That is so sad. Shabat shalom, kol ha cavod.
I quit the "Twit"over a year ago for exactly the same reasons. Peace.

As he explained in another article, he observed them and showed them to others in part to prove that this stuff really still exists.  There's a generation or two that thinks hook nosed caricatures etc. are only found in dusty old history books.  Nobody really does that anymore, do they?  Yup, they do.

Where I live there is a local news online website(WCAX) which requires Facebook accounts to comment. Doesn't stop the haters in the least. Every time someone of color is arrested, they are out and about like roaches when the light is turned on. A Hasidic Jew was ticketed for speeding and his pic was printed; wow did that bring out the hate as well. I'm guessing they must be proud of being haters and they get "likes" for these comments.

The same thing happened with CB radio. There was so much swearing going on that it turned my stomach, So i turned the switch off and put the radio on the shelf where it collects dust. It was a good idea which some people found a way to bully everybody else.
I would only use a social medium which required everyone to use their real name.

Facebook is like going to a cafe to have a reunion with an old high school friend, but Mark Zuckerberg sits down with you, records everything you say, tries to sell you products based on your conversation with your friend, and keeps bringing people to your table to introduce you and wish you happy birthday. Meanwhile he rifles through your phone and wallet, finds your contacts and photos, copies them and sells it to companies out the back door.

Conversely, Twitter is like a cocktail party where you invite only the celebrities and friends you want, and you can be part of every conversation in the room. If someone outside sneaks in to say offensive things, you can simply throw them out yourself by 'blocking' them.

Sounds like you want a bouncer to do it for you. Maybe they should help, but the power is in your hands if you want to use it.
Probably because he writes articles. Whom do you know who works with journalism who doesn't take advantage of social media? They are few and far between.
Perhaps a follow-on article - as a reasonably erudite individual - why were you ever on Twitter in the first place?
It is very clear that the decisions at Twitter (and Facebook) are based on lefty liberal standards of political correctness, and not common sense or decency.

Someone tell Concerned Citizen that Twitter is not a person with political views which threaten her whatever, it is a business motivated to increase profits. Money. Get it? They want money, not your hard earned right-wing soul. Common Sense? Does not apply. Decency? No longer required.

I once made a fake Twitter account pretending to be the Pope (the previous Pope, the one who wore lots of gold and red Prada loafers). I called it "pontifexfalsum" or so it was pretty obviously a parody account, and it made fun of the Pope not of Catholicism and was fact based: the Vatican bank scandals, cover up of child abuse, etc. Twitter blocked it as a violation of their TOS within 2 days after I got a retweet from Dan Savage and had started to build followers. After days of trying to contact Twitter they unblocked my account but it was blocked again in another day. I gave up. If they can do that, they could block the haters.

Good for you. If only more people could come to the same conclusion, that Twitter - like many other internet environments - is a realm in which the cowardly and the weak-minded thrive. I mean seriously - Twitter? Who cares what a bunch of losers wallowing in their mother's basements say or think? I suspect outlets like Twitter may even serve as a sort of safety valve for borderline psychopaths and others with anger & personality disorders. The yapping of dogs...it amounts exactly to that, nothing more.

Exactly. Twitter has online help. This looks relevant:

Blocking accounts on Twitter
https://support.twitter.com/articles/117063#

Yes, and calling them racist, too.  I really lost my sympathy for his plight with that remark.  Being the deputy Washington editor for the New York Times, shouldn't this man at least pretend impartiality?  He's not a blogger or an op ed writer.

Au contraire! I've seen too many posts by Bernie fans invoking sentiments regarding HRC like, "where is Oswald when we need him?"

There is plenty of hate going on in the Bernie Camp.

Yeah, I have screenshots of mean Hillary tweeters too, including some who are high profile people, not just Joe Six Pack with anon account. Comments & images disparaging Bernie's Jewishness, hammer & sickle graphics and every one of the 550 ways to call someone else stupid.

This editor covers politics. He needs a thicker skin and a refresher course in unbiased journalism Full stop.

I sympathize and have placed the ((( ))) around my own Twitter name. But one comment in your op-ed struck me as discordant: listing a small group of Sanders supporters in the same sentence as alt-right neofascists seems a bit much.

Not to go off on a tangent but I couldn't help mentioning. I lived for the last 5 years in Saudi Arabia. Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal is one of the biggest voices for liberalization of Saudi society and is considered highly suspect by the nation's religious elite. Prince Alwaleed employs many women in his organization and insists that they are free to dress entirely as they choose while at work. He also advocates for the Saudi recognition of Israel and supports a 2 state solution.

It is a common mistake to paint ALL Saudis with the same broad brush. This is nothing but another form of prejudice. We must keep our minds clear and our eyes open, so that when someone like Prince Alwaleed comes along, someone we can work with to make the world a better place, we can hold up our end.

Social media is a misnomer. In reality it's social marketing, commercial technology to deliver marketing data to corporate strategists and media agencies. Big data for the big sell. Twitter gathers, analyzes and packages its data stream generated by free content from dupes who use it and sells to corporations who further slide and dice data to spot opportunities, identify potential markets, design messages or ads, drive marketing campaigns, measure cost-efficiency, plan product inventory and distribution, even project staffing needs.

In the hands of social scientists and political operatives, Twitter data yields powerful political intelligence and facilitates targeting of customized content to specific groups.

Twitter is a powerful tool for developing and advancing hidden agenda that serve special interests often in conflict with public interest or democratic values of accountability and transparency.

As for Twitter's tolerance of anti-Semitic users, its second largest shareholder is billionaire Saudi Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal Bin Abdulaziz Alsaud. A related NYTimes article today reports how Saudi Arabia threatened to defund key UN humanitarian efforts for children if Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon didn't remove Saudi-backed militias from a UN report on war crimes against children, which was promptly done.

Benign appearance. Malignant intention. It's a corporate and political trap. Victims eagerly jump in.

It's America of, for and by twits.

This isn't about the haters winning. It is about standing up for what is right. Great decision to quit twitter after they wouldn't follow their own guidelines. Stunning to see how much hatred, racism, sexism still exists. Excellent to take a stand. Bravo.

The libraries still have books, for all of those looking elsewhere for healthy offline reading materials.

Some of the books today are actually worth reading, if you have discriminating eyeballs, and of course, there are always the time-tested classics that have survived.

(thankfully, even the much maligned "dead white men" are still available, if that is your personal preference... )

I sympathize with Twitter's victims. I really do. But isn't Twitter the perfect illustration of the old, "Lie down with dogs, get up with fleas," cliche? What would anyone expect of a medium that allows anonymous people to share their unmoderated comments with all humanity - in 140 characters?

For people who are targeted in a campaign, blocking users individually doesn't do much when they can create new accounts. It's possible to filter your timeline to include only people that you follow. But at that point, Twitter is nearly exactly like Facebook...not much point in maintaining two accounts.

"... on Facebook ..."

My name, being an close "doppelgänger" for the famous Facebook chief, gets me a decent amount of hate tweets - many are from anti-Semites. It just bangs home the obvious - these people are racist and incredibly stupid. And if Twitter refuses to deal with the problem, it makes sense not to deal with Twitter.
You missed the word "adopted", which means that the association is INVOLUNTARY.
If your thoughts can be condensed to 140 characters or less and are also never-ending, then they are about as welcome as bubbles in your bathtub.

"I gave up on all of those [social media] site types long ago ..."

When you post a comment, you are using "social media".
